column14: Existing Wording
column16: Ballot Comment

This is more outstanding work from the team!
The only comment I have would be to reference "Semantic Versioning" in the section on CQL Versioning.

1. The specification redefines L3 as a computable representation.  L3 was originally intended to be structured, precise, and unambiguous, but not necessarily computable. 
2. CQL should be optional.  While it is precise, it can be hard to review the large libraries of CQL expressions that would be needed for complex CDS scenarios.  Also, currently there are no widely available and easy to use tools for CQL authoring.  There may be simpler ways to express unambiguous guideline logic at the L3 level.

Perhaps it would be wise to include practicing clinicians as "end users (e.g., clinical implementation team representatives, health IT developers, patients/patient advocates)" since they would be the ones presented with the guideline recommendations and implementation may impact patient-clinician relationship and clinician burden.
There should also be an ongoing feedback loop from the field back to the development/implement cycle.  This is present in figure 2, but should be considered in process of figure 1.
CodeSystem-cpg-indicator: "Indicates that the recommendation is critical and the workflow should not be allowed to proceed" > when implemented, clinicians must not be blocked from their workflow - implementers should indicate level of concern and provide alternate pathway rather than workflow lock up (ie do not allow a hidden window to stop workflow).
CQL code - need to consider microalbumin result value as text "too low to detect" or null with comment field in following example:
define "Last UACR Quantity":
  "Last UACR Lab Result" Result
    return ToQuantity(Result.value as Quantity)
Recommendations should be brief and concise in pop up card but expandable for further detail to reduce interruption to clinical workflow.
Ideally, recommended actions should be capable of generating selectable order set.

Also, currently there are no widely available and easy to use tools for CQL authoring.  There may be simpler ways to express unambiguous guideline logic at the L3 level.

All the CPG profiles, in their example sections - XML, JSON, Turtle - have the respective profile page HTML content rendered as XML, JSON, etc.  This does not add to the understanding of the consumer of this IG as to how render CPG constrainted versions of the appropriate resource.
Please provide documentation on  how  Must Support on any data element SHALL be interpreted as.

Firms such as Milliman and InterQual currently provide clinical guidelines and software/systems which implement or utilize those guidelines, yet I don't see them represented as contributors or reviewers. I suggest that an effort be made as part of the evaluation or pilot of the specification that existing implementers within this space be engaged to evaluate using this specification for the expression of their guidelines. It is ecognized that their guidelines may be proprietary but that shouldn't impact on their use of this specification..
Why is the cardinality 0..1 for this and many other extensions? Under what circumstances would the extension be provided, given that it is optional, and yet not have content?

The slicing and fixed value requirements are overly prescriptive and should be reviewed to meet actual business needs; for example: not all patients are female so the fixed value for gender should not be female; and, not everyone has a mobile phone.

MustSupport is used extensively through the profiles and yet there is no definition of what MustSupport means in the context of these profiles. The IG should describe how MustSupport is used and how to check for conformance with MustSupport.

Why is this extension exclusive to CQF? It should be reviewed by the work group to determine whether this extension has a broarder potential applicability and be registered for as broad a use as is reasonable.

Why is this extension exclusive to CQF? It should be reviewed by the work group to determine whether this extension has a broarder potential applicability and be registered for as broad a use as is reasonable.

Why is this extension exclusive to CQF? It should be reviewed by the work group to determine whether this extension has a broarder potential applicability and be registered for as broad a use as is reasonable.

The slicing and fixed value requirements are overly prescriptive and should be reviewed to meet actual business needs; for example: why is the home address of the practitioner required but not the business address?

Why is this extension exclusive to CQF? It should be reviewed by the work group to determine whether this extension has a broarder potential applicability and be registered for as broad a use as is reasonable.
The 'y' flags do not appear to align with the headings.
I can see what appear to be examples of resources nut not definitions as suggested by the title  "Artifacts defined as part of the FHIR Clinical Guidelines Implementation Guide".

column14: If required, code systems defined by content conforming to this IG SHALL use the cpg-codesystem profile.
column16: While it is recognized that the information provided in the extensions may be required, it is noted that profiles or projects creating their own profiles on Codesystem or ValueSet makes implementations brittle.

column14: The library version number SHALL follow the convention: ..
column16: Unclear whether there is text meissing or whether the text following is the 'convention'.
The Library.topic has an example binding and yet is flagged MustSupport, what is the implementer expected to support - that is, is any Code System actually allowed and intended?

MedicationRequest contains numberous example bindings which don't provide interoperable guidance. 
This is also an issue for many of the stated profiles.

SNOMED is used in several of the CPG valuesets and yet this is a UV specification where access to SNOMED cannot generaly be assured. Are the codes used ones which SNOMED has authorized for unlicensed use?

In this profile, and possibly every profile where the extension is used, the binding for the extensions: strengthOfRecommendation and evidence-quality and 'example' bindings. What is the actual guidance?

Review of the IG shows that the topics addressed are comprehensive-it is unclear what the runtime or a test run of the guidelines generates for the end user in terms of consistent, error free guidance for patient care delivery based on the guideline. The principles expressed of standardizing the process of implementation to be consistent in application and reduce the effort for local implementations are important. A question I would pose is what is the science of the process used to codify the translation of guidelines into a digital process that delivers proven, error free (based on current guidelines) results; supporting patient safety as well as improved outcomes for the user community (care delivery organizations, providers, and patients)?

Great work.  Recommend more detailed description of how to start from narrative guidelines, then get to this form, then get to execution. I.e., a step-by-step guide where others can start from a clinical guideline and end up with executable artifacts. I believe this will make it a lot easier to consume the content.
column17: More detailed walkthrough of how to express content in proposed format and use it in actual systems.

column16: Recommend making the knowledge representation FHIR version independent of the underlying data version.  I.e., that an R4-based representation of a clinical guideline could be used to execute on data from R4, STU3, DSTU2, etc., and also with QICore FHIR profiles, or EHR vendor A's profiles, or USCore FHIR profiles, etc., in each version of FHIR.  Otherwise, copies of the knowledge resource would need to be created for each version of FHIR, and/or each flavor/profile of FHIR within that version.  Perhaps a given knowledge resource could work against multiple FHIR versions, or a logical model that can span multiple versions of FHIR.
column17: Make version of schema used for knowledge representation independent of version/profiles of patient data used by the knowledge

column15: Add clinical practice guideline authors to intended audience
column16: CPG authors will play prominent role in iterative approach described by implementation guide

This section refers to a common clinical pathway http://hl7.org/fhir/uv/cpg/2019SEP/common-pathway.html. It's unclear how complete or exhaustive this is meant to be, but the diagram implies a sequential set of activities. Health care is usually provided in parallel paths, e.g., testing, counseling, diagnosing (provisional, final), prescribing, etc. tend to happen simultaneously except for very straightforward chief complaints and diagnoses (e.g., sore threat and strep pharyngitis).

It's unclear where the recommendation instances came from or how exhaustive the list is meant to be to represent the full range of actions available to a healthcare provider (or other member of a care team). Consider expanding the list. Previous research has identified action types relvant to CPGs: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC1480124/

column4: 10.0.0 L2 checklist, 11.0.0 L3 checklist, 12.0.0 L4 checklist
column16: A central issue that this implementation guide can help address is to provide standardized way of recording how one (or set of people more likely) "traveled" from L1 to L4 so that the decisions made and the assumptions that impacted those decisions are fully documented. It will be important to account for the history of the iterative approach described in the background, which in turn will be essential to trustworthy sharing and dissemination among stakeholders who need to decide whether they can make those same assumptions and should make those same decisions. Examples include: why a particular value set (or member of a value set) was chosen or not, why certain events for ECA rules were identified but others were not considered, etc. The checklists provided may help somewhat, but the checklists seem to be more of a tool in planning rather than a tool for documentation after decisions have been made. Please provide guidance on where/how/when developers and implementers should record why they made these decisions/assumptions so that they can be more consistently discoverable by themselves and others afterward.
The Common Care Pathway diagram and the descriptions below the diagram do not always match. For example, there is no registration included in the diagram.

Goals - Indirect
Is there an expectation of improved patient outcomes from a larger and standard based implementation of these clinical guidelines?

column14: recommendations should be well-vetted and more readily implemented.
column15: recommendations should be well-vetted and more readily implemented across multiple clinical domains.

column16: The figure 1.2 shows a link that about delivering actionable knowledge to community services. There is not a standard for this type of knowledge transfer nor are there standard representations or standard knowledge representations for all community service organizations/providers at least as far as I know. However, there is a standard to deliver this type of knowledge to public health departments. For the instances where the community service provider is a known entity, this representation is workable, but for the those cases where this community service information is local, the use of the public health department (state and/or local) as a broker for the request of these services would be an acceptable resource to link or match these community service requests. For example, home inspections for lead exposure or for an asthma prevention reccomendation, local excercise facilities when a Y is not in the jursidiction, or for locating members of the homeless community.
column17: Public health standards for knowledge distribution

column4: Artifacts defined as part of the FHIR Clinical Guidelines Implementation Guide
column16:
Several  (all?) artifacts listed under the Library Reseources show CQL libraries, in which the most interesting part (the logic) is not visible beacause it is Base64 encoded. As a result looking at these examples does not feel useful for the reader. 
Specific example: http://hl7.org/fhir/uv/cpg/2019SEP/Library-ckd-risk-recommendations.json.html
Throughout the IG, all references used in the examples refer to resources with IDs that contain underscores. This is not allowed. Also, the referred to resouces do not have an id field.
column17: References in examples include underscores in ids.

column16: Examples relate to FHIR STU1, STU3 and R4. It would be helpful if the set of resources of each release can be downloaded separately.
The standard assumes behavior that is not specified in the different STU versions. E.g. that actions will only be called if the trigger  is fired. Such behavior should be defined.

The specification does not define how to use it in a clinical context, neither do the underlying FHIR versions.
E.g. most PlanDefinitions depend on triggers. When the trigger is activated, the PlanDefinition is applied. 
How does this integrate in clinical practice? Questions related to this include: 1 Does this happen in the background and is the clinician notified when this has happened? 2 Does the specification assume that this happens directly when the triggers are fired?

The specification defines the PlanDefinitions but not the process to be taken once the PlanDefinition has been applied, neither do the underlying FHIR versions. Please define what is expected to be done with each CarePlan/RequestGroup. Is it to be stored? Is this up to the implementer? What happens with the actions that result from the Careplan? Are they to be documented within the CarePlan? Please explain.

column14: 1.5.0 Background
column16: Over at least the past two decades, there have been several major attempts to accomplish what this guide proposes to do. These previous attempts have been well studied and evaluated. One example is GEM, but ther have been others. All of the previous efforts to code guidelines failed. This background section fails to address the history of CPG coding attempts, and there is no discussion of attempts to learn from the previous failures. This section should describe previous attempts, lessons learned, and reasons why the chosen approach is any more likely to be successful than the other atempts.
column17: Address the history of attempts to code CPGs.

column16: Structuring Recommendations: Please explain why existing FHIR constructs, including Patient, PractitionerRole, and the practice-codes value set are not specified. Is the community really ready to adopt this orthoganal approach?

There is no description of the process to be used to move from the narrative guideline to the L3 artifacts. One of the reasons for previous failures was that clinical experts were incapable of performing the needed coding, and the coders did not understand the nuances of recomendations. What is the tooling and steps to be performed by which experts to perform accurate conversiions?
There needs to be a complete example of the artifacts involved in moving from L1 to L3 for a single complex guideline so that implementers can see the whole process.

Where is a coded example of a set of guideline recommendations that includes coding for concepts such as strenght of recommendation, quality of evidence, and links from coded recommendations back to the narrative text? Even at L4, clinicians are going to expect that this information is readily available.
column17: Coded CPGs cannot be black boxes.
